Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intra-operative Ventilation Strategies in Obese Patients

Background: Intra-operative ventilation with low/physiological tidal volume and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) with periodic alveolar recruitment manoeuvres (ARMs) is recommended for obese surgical patients. This study aimed to investigate the effects of different PEEP levels and ARMs on ventilation distribution, oxygenation, haemodynamic parameters, and cerebral oximetry.

Methods: This substudy of a randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary medical centre in Geneva, Switzerland, from 2015 to 2018. Participants included 162 patients with a BMI of at least 35 kg/m² undergoing elective open or laparoscopic surgery lasting at least 120 minutes. Patients were randomised to receive either PEEP of 4 cmH₂O (n = 79) or PEEP of 12 cmH₂O with hourly ARMs (n = 83). The primary outcome was the fraction of ventilation in the dependent lung, measured by electrical impedance tomography over the intra-operative period. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was not applicable.

Results: High PEEP was associated with smaller decreases in dependent lung ventilation (-11.2%; 95% CI -8.7 to -13.7 vs. -13.9%; 95% CI -11.7 to -16.5; P = 0.029) and a lower driving pressure (-6.3 cmH₂O; 95% CI -5.7 to -7.0). Haemodynamic parameters were similar between groups, except for transient decreases in arterial pressure and cardiac index at the end of ARMs.

Interpretation: In obese patients undergoing abdominal surgery, PEEP of 12 cmH₂O with ARMs slightly improved ventilation distribution and oxygenation compared to PEEP of 4 cmH₂O.

Trial registration: NCT02148692

Funding: Not specified.
